summary: This is a DOJ Office of the Inspector General interview transcript from August 4, 2021, with a Federal Bureau of Prisons facilities manager at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The interview focuses on the camera system failures at MCC on August 9-10, 2019, surrounding the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein, and the witness's knowledge of the events and personnel involved.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at MCC New York, an apparent suicide by hanging.

events.title: Camera System Failure at MCC
events.description: The camera recording system at MCC failed, with multiple hard drives down, resulting in no recording in the SHU (except one camera) during the period leading to Epstein's death.

events.title: OIG Interview of BOP Facilities Manager
events.description: DOJ Office of the Inspector General interviews BOP facilities manager Nobile about the camera failures and circumstances surrounding Epstein's death.

events.title: Tovar Discovers Camera Failure
events.description: Electronic technician Tovar allegedly discovered the camera recorders were not recording at the end of his shift (~2 PM) and claims he notified a supervisor, who told him to fix it the next day.

locations: Metropolitan Correction Center (MCC), New York, New York
SHU (Special Housing Unit) - Ten South, MCC
keyFacts: The camera recording system at MCC was not working properly on August 9-10, 2019; only one camera in the SHU was recording, which captured footage outside Epstein's cell.
BOP employee Tovar, the only comtech at the time, allegedly discovered the failure on August 9 but was told to fix it the next day.
Facilities manager Nobile was on vacation August 9-10, 2019, and has no specific recollection of being notified about the camera failure.
The camera system was old, antiquated, and a replacement project had been initiated in 2018 but was not completed by August 2019.
Access to the physical camera recorders was controlled by the SIS unit; only comtechs like Tovar had administrative rights to take cameras offline via the software.
